Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions US-China: Collaborative Research: Phylogenetic, Functional, and Genetic Diversity and Ecosystem Functions in a Fragmented Landscape
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project ? jointly funded with the Chinese National Science Foundation (NSFC) ? will study the relationships among ecological/evolutionary measures of biodiversity, and ecosystem functions. In particular, the investigators will investigate the hypothesis that succession drives changes in biodiversity, which in turn causes altered ecosystem function. Researchers will study the biodiversity of plant and insect assemblages on islands in the Thousand-Island Lake in China. This man-made lake was created in 1959 as the result of dam construction. As the water level rose, previously continuous terrestrial habitats were fragmented into islands. The project will investigate three dimensions of biodiversity on islands of different successional stages, their interrelationships, and linkages to ecosystem function. Field surveys of plant and insect communities will be combined with experimental manipulations of biodiversity, and laboratory-based functional and genetic analyses of plant and insect samples to examine biodiversity and ecosystem function patterns in this unusual habitat.

The proposed research will allow this international team to gain a better understanding of linkages among the multiple dimensions of biodiversity, ecosystem function, and habitat fragmentation, by taking advantage of the highly replicated, natural, insular environment of Thousand-Island Lake. This project will serve as a long-term platform for collaborations between US and Chinese scientists and students. Results of this study will be disseminated through publications in peer-reviewed journals, conference presentations, and teaching/training activities. The project will provide high-quality research opportunities for young scientists and students through hands-on research and via organized workshops. It will emphasize the involvement of underrepresented groups in science via existing student outreach programs at the researchers' home institutions. The researchers will work with local managers and tourist groups on the Thousand-Island Lake islands to promote public education about biodiversity in the face of habitat fragmentation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Almost all Earth’s ecosystems are subject to the influence of human activities, resulting in the transformation of previously continuous habitats into isolated habitat fragments. Much research on habitat fragmentation has focused on its effect on species diversity (that is, the number of species found in an ecological community), which constitutes a key dimension of biodiversity. However, biodiversity has other dimensions, which are no less important than species diversity, and we know little about how habitat fragmentation affects these other biodiversity dimensions, as well as how these other biodiversity dimensions affect the functioning of ecosystems across the fragmented landscape. The goal of this US-China collaborative research project was to understand patterns of multiple dimensions of biodiversity of plant, arthropod, and microbial assemblages, ecological processes driving these patterns, and the linkage between multiple biodiversity dimensions and ecosystem functions (e.g., plant biomass production) on the islands of the Thousand-Island Lake (hereafter TIL) of China – the lake with the most islands in the world (1,100 islands). This project involved researchers from two US institutions (Georgia Institute of Technology and Arizona State University) and four Chinese institutions (East China Normal University, Hangzhou Normal University, Zhejiang University, and Zhejiang Agriculture & Forestry University).

This project, led by Dr. Lin Jiang at Georgia Tech, has produced several significant and novel findings. First, the researchers have demonstrated the existence of a plant successional gradient on the TIL islands, such that ecological succession proceeded further and later successional species were present on larger islands, confirming the overarching hypothesis of their project. Second, they found that species, functional, phylogenetic, and genetic diversity of plants and arthropods, as well as species and phylogenetic diversity of soil bacteria and fungi, were all greater on larger islands. Using a novel analytic tool they developed, the researchers also found that different ecological mechanisms were behind the similar species diversity-island size relationships for soil bacteria and fungi. Mechanisms underlying the observed plant species diversity-island size relationship were also identified. Third, the researchers have found that strikingly different ecological mechanisms were responsible for determining the properties of soil bacterial and fungal communities, with island size influencing ecological network properties in opposite directions for soil bacteria and fungi.    

An important component of this research program was to provide high-quality training for future scientists in innovative ecological research. During the 68-month period, this project has trained three postdoctoral fellows, two Ph.D. students, three M.S. students, and over two dozens of undergraduate researchers. These individuals gained valuable experience in experimental design, data collection and analysis, and manuscript writing.

This project has produced a total of 38 peer-reviewed publications.
